channel.title: Zune Or iPod
channel.description:
Im buying a Zune as soon as they are released in Australia. And I would like to ask everyone which is better a Zune or an Ipod. I personally think the zune is better (in my opinion). Bigger screen, customizability and WiFi etc. So yeah. Here are some comparisons of the two:
Specifications
* 4.4 × 2.4 × 0.58-inch (11.2 × 6.1 × 1.4 cm) * 5.6 ounces (158.8 grams) * 802.11b/g built-in Wi-Fi * 30 GB hard drive * 3-inch QVGA LCD screen, with a resolution of 320×240, 65k/16-bit color screen * Radio Data System enabled FM receiver * Native support for MP3, AAC (.mp4), WMA: WMA Pro (2-channel), WMV, JPEG. Foreign format transcoding from MP4 to WMV.[15] * Charge Time: 3 hours; 2 hours to 90%[16] * With Wi-Fi turned on, up to 13 hours battery life when playing music (optimal conditions) * With Wi-Fi turned off, up to 14 hours battery life when playing music, 4 hours playing video or viewing pictures.[17] * Operating system: Based on Portable Media Center / Windows CE. * CPU: Freescale i. MX31L processor; ARM Core, FPU (SCIMX31LVKM5 / 3L38W / CTAU0629) * RAM: 64 MBytes x32 Mobile SDR DRAM / 133 MHz / 90 mA (K4M51323PC-DG75) [3] * Flash: 2 MBytes NOR flash, 3.3V, 1Mx16 Boot block (PH28F160C3TD) [4] * FS456LF: radio PC to TV video scan converter (Macrovision 7) * Audio: Stereo CODEC with speaker driver / 0.9 W power out (WM8978G) [5] * FM Tuner: Silicon Labs Si4701 single-chip radio tuner (4701A15) [6] * TV out: Focus (FS456) [7] * USB: USB2.0 Philips (ISP1504) [8] * bus switch: Low voltage octal FET bus switch (CL245 / SN74CBTLV3245A) [9] * ATA driver (?): 8-bit bus transceiver/driver (P003 / 620A5) * Wi-Fi: RF/BB/MAC 802.11g Wi-Fi (KeyStream) module (KS3021 / KS7010) * Power manager: Freescale MC13783 [10] * Battery: Li-Ion battery 3.7 V / 800 mAh (G71C0006Z110) * Hard Disk: Toshiba 30 GB hard disk, 1.8" (MK3008GAL) [11] * Each Zune comes with earphones, USB data cable, and carrying bag.
The Zune also comes with alot of preloaded content 10+ music videos and songs, Pictures of graffiti art and rock posters etc. And some short films.
Accessories
Zune accessories sold separately include:
* Charging devices (car adapter, AC wall-socket adapters, external battery). * I/O adapters (A/V composite, FM transmitters, headphones, USB data cable). * Docks (charging, multimedia large speaker, vertical hands-free assist). * Protection (glass screen protection, hardened/cushioning material case protection). * Carrying cases (standard issue, armband type). * Replacement parts and upgrades (battery, hard drive, LCD, etc.) .
There is a great comparison of them here: http://www.zunescene.com/comparison/
[img]http://www.zunescene.com/zune-pictures/zune_squeeze.jpg[/img] [img]http://www.zunescene.com/compare.jpg[/img] [img]http://www.zunescene.com/soup3.jpg[/img] [img]http://www.zunescene.com/orange15.jpg[/img]

item.title: Zune Or iPod
item.dc:creator: @Krichevskoy Krichevskoy
item.description:
@Krichevskoy wrote:

[quote=“DeadBird, post:11, topic:70127”]iPod is overpriced crap. Zune isn’t overpriced - but still crap.
Sansa e280 is the way to go![/quote]

I actually am looking for an iPod alternative, because they are overpriced. The problem is storage - my music library has apparently reached a size most people label ridiculous. As far as I know, nothing rivals an iPod for storage to cost and nothing else even offers 60GB+ models. I look at, say, the Creative players and like them, but at 8GB they just don’t cut it.

YourDistracted:

Just because its made by microsoft doesn’t mean its bad. Its a really good product. I’ve had an iPod it sucked ass. I have tried out the model that the zune is based on and its really good. But you have me there with five generations of refinement. Although I havent seen much diffrence through the generations of the iPod.

Each generation tends to have more storage and more features for less cost. They follow a price scheme kind of like video card manufacturers: when they come out with a newer and better model it takes over their highest price point and everything lesser is adjusted down.

And no, just because it’s Microsoft doesn’t mean it’s bad. It just means that there’s a much higher probability of having to put up with a lot of bullshit. Look up “Zune” and “PlaysForSure” to see what I mean. They don’t even support their own standards.

Of course, with Apple you have to put up with attempts to kill your player if you’ve kept it working too long (an “updater bug” indeed), horrible support (do they still charge you almost the price of a new iPod to replace a battery?), and the obnoxious marketing image. I doubt if Microsoft is any better with those things, but I’ve had firsthand experience with Apple.

Read full topic

@exe626 wrote:

Its gonna take along time for Zune to be dominate if its brand-new.
Especially if nobody knows about it, so it won’t be popular for awhile.

Personally I’d go for the player that’s been through five generations of refinement and isn’t a Microsoft product.[/quote]

item.title: Zune Or iPod
item.dc:creator: @YourDistracted YourDistracted
item.description:
@YourDistracted wrote:

Im buying a Zune as soon as they are released in Australia. And I would like to ask everyone which is better a Zune or an Ipod. I personally think the zune is better (in my opinion). Bigger screen, customizability and WiFi etc. So yeah. Here are some comparisons of the two:

Specifications

* 4.4 × 2.4 × 0.58-inch (11.2 × 6.1 × 1.4 cm)
* 5.6 ounces (158.8 grams)
* 802.11b/g built-in Wi-Fi
* 30 GB hard drive
* 3-inch QVGA LCD screen, with a resolution of 320×240, 65k/16-bit color screen
* Radio Data System enabled FM receiver
* Native support for MP3, AAC (.mp4), WMA: WMA Pro (2-channel), WMV, JPEG. Foreign format transcoding from MP4 to WMV.[15]
* Charge Time: 3 hours; 2 hours to 90%[16]
* With Wi-Fi turned on, up to 13 hours battery life when playing music (optimal conditions)
* With Wi-Fi turned off, up to 14 hours battery life when playing music, 4 hours playing video or viewing pictures.[17]
* Operating system: Based on Portable Media Center / Windows CE.
* CPU: Freescale i. MX31L processor; ARM Core, FPU (SCIMX31LVKM5 / 3L38W / CTAU0629) 
* RAM: 64 MBytes x32 Mobile SDR DRAM / 133 MHz / 90 mA (K4M51323PC-DG75) [3]
* Flash: 2 MBytes NOR flash, 3.3V, 1Mx16 Boot block (PH28F160C3TD) [4]
* FS456LF: radio PC to TV video scan converter (Macrovision 7)
* Audio: Stereo CODEC with speaker driver / 0.9 W power out (WM8978G) [5]
* FM Tuner: Silicon Labs Si4701 single-chip radio tuner (4701A15) [6]
* TV out: Focus (FS456) [7]
* USB: USB2.0 Philips (ISP1504) [8]
* bus switch: Low voltage octal FET bus switch (CL245 / SN74CBTLV3245A) [9]
* ATA driver (?): 8-bit bus transceiver/driver (P003 / 620A5)
* Wi-Fi: RF/BB/MAC 802.11g Wi-Fi (KeyStream) module (KS3021 / KS7010)
* Power manager: Freescale MC13783 [10]
* Battery: Li-Ion battery 3.7 V / 800 mAh (G71C0006Z110)
* Hard Disk: Toshiba 30 GB hard disk, 1.8" (MK3008GAL) [11]
* Each Zune comes with earphones, USB data cable, and carrying bag.

The Zune also comes with alot of preloaded content 10+ music videos and songs, Pictures of graffiti art and rock posters etc. And some short films.

Accessories

Zune accessories sold separately include:

* Charging devices (car adapter, AC wall-socket adapters, external battery).
* I/O adapters (A/V composite, FM transmitters, headphones, USB data cable).
* Docks (charging, multimedia large speaker, vertical hands-free assist).
* Protection (glass screen protection, hardened/cushioning material case protection).
* Carrying cases (standard issue, armband type).
* Replacement parts and upgrades (battery, hard drive, LCD, etc.) .

There is a great comparison of them here:
http://www.zunescene.com/comparison/




Read full topic
